exam.summary: EXAM SCENARIO: During a training simulation, a warp core begins showing minor plasma instability, threatening system integrity. This is your final engineering qualification test. Your decisions here will determine your readiness to serve as Chief Engineer aboard a Federation starship.

answers.text: Engage intermix calibration and verify magnetic constrictor fields before correcting plasma flow.
answers.details: Follows full safety protocols and ensures containment integrity, demonstrating disciplined engineering leadership.

answers.text: Divert power from secondary systems to reinforce plasma injectors while running core diagnostics.
answers.details: Sound engineering solution, though riskier without first confirming constrictor field stability.

answers.text: Run a rapid plasma flush to clear the conduits before diagnostics complete.
answers.details: Quick but risky; could worsen instability if the cause is electromagnetic feedback rather than blockage.

answers.text: Increase warp field output to mask fluctuation readings and maintain power balance.
answers.details: Overdriving the warp field in an unstable plasma condition violates Starfleet safety procedures.

answers.text: Ignore readings; fluctuations at this level typically self-correct.
answers.details: Neglecting a plasma irregularity risks containment breach and catastrophic drive failure.

exam.summary: EXAM SCENARIO: During bridge maneuvers, the Engineering console alerts to a rising EPS pressure spike across three decks. This is your final engineering qualification test. Your decisions here will determine your readiness to serve as Chief Engineer aboard a Federation starship.

answers.text: Isolate the affected conduits and reroute power through auxiliary transfer nodes.
answers.details: Textbook containment procedure per Starfleet power management guidelines.

answers.text: Manually vent plasma from the EPS manifold to stabilize flow immediately.
answers.details: Effective in emergencies but risks radiation exposure if performed outside containment protocols.

answers.text: Trigger a shipwide power reset to reinitialize EPS regulators.
answers.details: Can work, but causes total systems loss and violates operational safety during maneuvers.

answers.text: Bypass flow regulators and run power directly to maintain output.
answers.details: Bypassing regulators risks a cascade failure and violates engineering safety codes.

answers.text: Allow the surge to dissipate naturally; pressure will normalize post-maneuver.
answers.details: Ignoring EPS pressure anomalies can cause conduit rupture and deck-level fire risk.

exam.summary: EXAM SCENARIO: Engineering reports a coolant leak in the impulse drive assembly during atmospheric operations. This is your final engineering qualification test. Your decisions here will determine your readiness to serve as Chief Engineer aboard a Federation starship.

answers.text: Shut down the affected engine, reroute thrust, and activate emergency coolant seals.
answers.details: Safely neutralizes the fault and preserves ship control per Starfleet mechanical safety standards.

answers.text: Engage auxiliary venting to space and continue low-thrust operation until stable orbit is achieved.
answers.details: Acceptable short-term fix but risks atmospheric contamination.

answers.text: Divert coolant through the warp intercooler grid to maintain system temperature.
answers.details: Works temporarily but risks contamination of warp coolant circuits.

answers.text: Increase engine output to vaporize leaking coolant faster.
answers.details: Thermal overdrive under leak conditions can rupture manifolds and ignite plasma conduits.

answers.text: Deactivate alarms and log the incident for later review.
answers.details: Ignoring leaks endangers crew and ship; violates Federation safety directives.
